en: Interview with Charlie Cole, 2020-10-26

Interview with Charlie Cole, fire chief fo the city of Gatlinburg. Cole discusses the time leading up to the fire along with the conditions that led to so much devastation. He also recounts the night of the wildfires in terms of the fire department's logistics and operations to combat the disaster. This is a representative quote from the interview: "We switched to an evacuation rescue mode to where the police and the fire, all the first responders, all the additional resources switched over to an evacuation and rescue mode. We actually, the numbers say, that we evacuated 14,000, approximately, people in Gatlinburg surrounding area of the county and Gatlinburg area that night."

This is a representative quote from the interview: "We switched to an evacuation rescue mode to where the police and the fire, all the first responders, all the additional resources switched over to an evacuation and rescue mode. Interview with Charlie Cole, 2020-10-26 -- Gatlinburg
Captions in English
Bibliographic Description in MODS
Interview with Charlie Cole, 2020-10-26
Interview Questions
Can you state your name and tell us about your background?
Outside of your work with the fire department, can you talk about your involvement with the community?
What were your experiences in the days and weeks leading up to the wildfires in 2016?
When were you first notified about the fire on Chimney Tops?
So there was a lot of smoke on the day of the fire? At what point were you concerned that the fire could come into the city?
In your role at that time, what were the operational logistics or activities that you were undertaking that day?
What transpired when you and your colleagues first realized the wildfires were entering Gatlinburg?
What happened as the fire started coming out of Twin Creeks and into Gatlinburg? Could you talk about the direction the fire ended up taking?
What were your experiences that evening as the fire progressed and communications began with other fire departments that came into the city?
Were you based at the fire department that evening or somewhere else?
What was it like at the command center? What were some personal feelings from that night you felt as a resident of Gatlinburg?
Are there any memories from that evening that have stuck with you?
What transpired as the night went on? What kind of direction was given to the fire department?
How did the weather shift that night? When the rain came, what transpired next?
Were there other urgent issues besides evacuation that you dealt with that evening?
Did you have any challenges with lack of communication?
Is there anything else about the night of the wildfires that you would like to share?
Moving to the following day, what were the most urgent issues in the days after the wildfires?
Can you describe the extent of the physical damage to the city?
Are there any memories from that time period following the fires that have stuck with you?
Are there any other ways that this event had a personal impact on you, either emotionally or otherwise?
Can you discuss any new disaster response plans that have been employed because of the 2016 wildfires?
Can you talk about what Fire Wise is for people who aren't familiar?
Can you talk about what Fire Wise is for people who aren't familiar?
How did the fires shape community relations?
Is there anything else surprising or good that came out of this event?
How would you say that the natural environment has recovered from the fires?
Is there anything that you would like to share about how the COVID-19 pandemic has impacted your work just a few years after the wildfires?
Is there anything that you would like to share that we haven't discussed?
